properties.description: Boston Tea Party: Samuel Adams and Sons of Liberty led American colonists in dumping 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor
Tea Act of 1773 granted British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales in American colonies

The mechanism through which the Tea Act led to rebellion: (1) Tea Act imposed taxation without representation, violating self-governance; (2) Created economic pressure on merchants and ideological mobilization; (3) Sons of Liberty channeled discontent; (4) Resistance culminated in direct action.
Imperial control mechanism: legislative component (Tea Act) created economic and political pressures to test colonial loyalty and extract revenue.
Ideological mobilization transforms abstract principles into concrete collective action.
The American Revolution was primarily driven by colonial resistance based on constitutional principles (e.g., taxation without representation).
Principled opposition, rather than mere economic grievance, drove colonial resistance.
Enlightenment ideas influenced colonial thinking.
A coordinated communication network existed among colonial leaders.
Constitutional concerns override economic interests in colonial motivation.
Constitutional language in private correspondence reflects genuine beliefs rather than just political rhetoric.
Revolution driven by material interests / economic grievances rather than ideological commitment.
The revolution was primarily driven by colonial merchants' economic interests rather than constitutional principles.
key_predictions: disproportionate merchant leadership in revolutionary activities
focus on trade policy over representation issues

properties.description: Colonial elites deliberately manufactured popular outrage to advance their own political ambitions.
key_predictions: revolutionary rhetoric concentrated among educated elite

properties.description: French agents and financial support were the primary drivers of colonial rebellion.
key_predictions: early French involvement and financial backing before 1775

properties.description: European balance-of-power considerations influenced colonial resistance more than previously recognized.

properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.intentions: Mobilize mass resistance against British authority
properties.beliefs: British rule fundamentally violated colonial rights
properties.constraints: Need to maintain legitimacy and avoid alienating moderate colonists

properties.name: Governor Thomas Hutchinson
properties.beliefs: Colonists were ungrateful subjects who needed firm governance
properties.constraints: Limited military resources, need to maintain order
properties.capabilities: Formal governmental authority but limited practical enforcement power

properties.name: King George III
properties.intentions: Maintain imperial control and extract revenue
properties.beliefs: Colonies as subordinate territories existing to benefit Britain
properties.constraints: Distance, communication delays, competing European threats
properties.capabilities: British military and navy, limited by costs and logistics of transatlantic warfare

properties.source_text_quote: This dramatic act of rebellion was the direct result of the Tea Act of 1773
The mechanism through which the Tea Act led to rebellion operated as follows
(1) The Tea Act imposed taxation without colonial representation in Parliament, violating fundamental principles of self-governance
(2) This created both economic pressure on local merchants who were undercut by the monopoly and ideological mobilization around constitutional principles
(3) Groups like the Sons of Liberty channeled this discontent into organized resistance
(4) The resistance culminated in direct action against British property

The Boston Tea Party was a critical component part of the larger imperial resistance mechanism, serving as the decisive trigger event that transformed abstract constitutional grievances into concrete revolutionary action.

The Boston Tea Party was a critical component part of the larger imperial resistance mechanism, serving as the decisive trigger event that transformed abstract constitutional grievances into concrete revolutionary action.

The Tea Act itself was part of the imperial control mechanism, serving as the legislative component that created the economic and political pressures necessary to test colonial loyalty and extract revenue from the American territories.

properties.scope: showing that principled opposition...created the necessary conditions
properties.source_text_quote: The constitutional principle hypothesis explains how the imperial resistance mechanism operates by showing that principled opposition to taxation without representation created the necessary conditions for organized resistance.
This hypothesis explains that the mechanism functions through ideological mobilization that transforms abstract principles into concrete collective action.

The economic grievance hypothesis explains the mechanism differently, proposing that the mechanism operates through material interests rather than ideological commitment, with merchants using constitutional rhetoric to disguise self-interested opposition to British trade policies.
